Ok, this review will probably be a tad long cause this is the resident evil i've been hoping to play the most, since everybody talks like its the worst game in the whole world

First of all, i think the main problem people had with this game was because they didn't get a proper item management, doing puzzles, checking the map for items resident evil since almightly resident evil 4 (dont remember if original re4 fulfills all those conditions though), so this means people were expecting the highest budget in the franchise to be an amazing games that goes back to its roots, it does not, so people got mad

This game is not bad, it's actually a good game, in terms of graphics, cool moments, explosions, quotes, characters, everything, this game is the best in the entire franchise, it has the biggest budget so it's obviously the one with the most work done in every single part of the game, this game is absolutely gorgeous even for the time

I'll first talk about the things i liked about this game. i'm not tryna spoil if you didn't play the game yet, but i'll assume you know the game has 4 campaigns and you do them in order. So, the duo for jake's campaign is absolutely awesome, i loved playing that campaign simply because of them, jake and sherry are amazing and their moments are so cool, for sure the best duo in this game.

However, it's not the best campaign overall, i'd give that spot to Ada's, it's the most fun and cool campaign for me, the weapons are different and cool, i loved playing with a crossbow, playing as ada is always cool, and the levels were fun for me, the worst campaign for me was chris's, then jake, then leon, then ada, in that order, Leon's campaign is good in all means, it's not that amazing but it's good in every moment

I also love the main aspect of the game of reuniting lots of the franchise's characters in the same spot, loved seeing sherry again and the fanservices between chris and leon, that's prob the biggest selling point for this game after all, loved playing with different characters

Now for the flaws, and oh good there are a lot, first of all, the game is part of the modern era (re4 - re6), so it is absolutely action focused, there is literally a button in this map that shows you the path you have to go, so most moments in the game are all go ahead and walk straight, kill enemies and keep walking straight, this makes the game extremely boring after some time, that is the biggest flaw in the game for me, alongside the fact that you go back in the same areas a lot of times since the characters's campaigns present all that they did, and they do have encounters, you end up making the same thing again

Also, the story doesn't seem to connect properly, sometimes i feel like there is no actual purpose on some characters being there, they are there only because why not, it doesn't feel like there's an objective at all, they were only placed that for whatever reason, i also feel like this game has an awful amount of instant death moments, that caught me on surprise, there were not so many on others games because of manual saving, but this game has atleast one per episode, sometimes more than one, and some of them are actually random

Now to finish with technical problems, the abilities system is awful, i don't like doing more damage or having higher crit because of "ability points" you spend, i love the upgrading weapons thing in other games, also, the herbs system is bad, and pressing esc to open options doesn't even pause the game, and you can't pause if ur match is set to online (took me 2 episodes to figure that out), i miss having to think about the items i get, and for a game where the inventory doesn't matter, having a cap on ammo, herbs and etc was pretty bad

The game is pretty good, i think one of the things that made me have as much fun as i had was because i played all of them before (and also played this one on ps3, so a bit of nostalgia, yeah i liked it a lot even though i said some flaws earlier lol) I'm the type of gamer to put having fun in a game almost all technical things, and this game is actually very good at making you have fun, yeah it's a very good game you can judge me

Overall: 8/10

Before I begin, though I am giving critiques, no I do not think RE6 is unplayable or not worth your time, I actually think it is quite fun! But here we go!

RE6 is not the traditional resident evil experience, not by a long shot. It is an action game through and through, despite Capcom's best efforts to make each campaign a "different" experience. Leon's campaign is probably the closest we get to "horror". Unfortunately, they also do not do a great job at linking each campaign together into one cohesive story. This is not aided by the fact that the story as a whole has a lot going on that is not well-explained even within the self-contained campaigns. I'll go into each campaign without spoiling, just what I think of each.

Leon/Helena- Like I said, this one is probably the closest to "horror" and is the best as a self-contained story. It doesn't largely intersect with Chris and Jake's campaigns outside of the major events where you play all together and maybe this is for the best. It has some good moments, Leon and Helena are good characters that work well together and the story is really not bad. Their gameplay sections are pretty alright as well imo. 

Chris/Piers- This campaign, in my opinion, has the best story in terms of character arcs. I won't go into too much detail because even though this game is old, I don't want to spoil. Chris has a good and sad character arc, and Piers is a perfect character to pair him with for this purpose. I was not a huge fan of the gameplay in this campaign if only because it is the action-heaviest one, with plenty of explosions and angry yelling. However, I think the drama and character makes up for it. The way it plays into the larger narrative is fine too, though I'm not going to applaud the overarching story of this game. 

Jake/Sherry- This is my personal favorite campaign. Jake's story is just as interesting as Chris's and again Sherry is a perfect partner to pair him with because of their chemistry and parallels. There is a stalker enemy throughout this campaign that feels like a Mr. X callback and this is pretty cool. Overall, I have similar things to say about gameplay/the overall story because that is a constant throughout all campaigns. 

Ada- You would think her campaign would tie up the loose ends and help us understand the story the best. This is not the case. I feel like the only reason I understand anything about this game is because of files and sources outside of it. This is not how you tell any story. I don't mind Ada's campaign, there are some good puzzles and her combat is pretty fun. It's just the story that brings it down for me. 

Ultimately, and kind of a TLDR- RE6 is not an irredeemable game. What it lacks in story and horror it makes up for in fun gameplay (including some pretty good melee and counterattacks that I have fun with, as well as a good co-op experience), and character stories. It's major weakness is unfortunately the narrative it is trying to tell regarding the C-Virus. It's character stories for Chris, Jake and his dad and their parallels between Piers and Sherry are actually very gripping in my opinion. It's just the outer-story that is weak, leaving Leon, Helena, and especially Ada (the center of this game's story) left with little to do. Overall, however, I think this game gets far too much hate and there is very much something to enjoy in it :)

Campaigns ranked: 
Leon - Best. Gives an effort to be a horror game. Atmosphere is at its best. The first two missions were the peak of the game for us. 

Jake - Alright. Jake and Sherry's characters carry this one, set pieces are alright. But they have good chemistry so it works. The bosses were fun, and the short bus nemesis was entertaining. 
 
Ada - Meh. Not Designed around Co-Op. Partner is just a generic "Agent" who has no dialogue or interaction with the story. Makes it feel less fun and more stupid when you see your Co-Op partner teleporting to you every time you have to open a door or grapple away. Story helps tie everything together so it should be done last to enjoy it fully. 

Chris - Worst. All action, very little horror. Feels like a call of duty campaign with a Resident Evil skin. The dialogue is very cringey, it feels like it was written by ChatGPT after being fed the script from a 360 shovelware war game. Plot feels super contrived from start to finish. You really want to like Piers because the dude is a human golden Retriever, but it falls flat because Chris's entire character arc is solved after a 1 minute conversation with Leon. You get 0 closure on anything that happened after RE5, and its as if RE5 never happened minus 2 minutes worth of scenes involving Jake. 

Overall the game shines when its not in China, the whole plotline involving China is weak and its areas all feel generic and samey minus one scene in the Leon campaign. They swapped the fun and satisfying combat system of RE4+5 for a modernized version of itself.

It feels like they took the complaints about QTEs and people saying "WHY CANT I DO THAT STUFF IN THE GAME!?"  and added it to the gameplay. Which just made everything terrible. People will try and say "But the movement tech bro!" when in reality the only movement tech you will ever really need to use (On Veteran anyway) is the dark souls roll forward.  The melee system would've felt much better if you didn't have to worry about managing a stamina bar, even if it was OP. It would've been far more enjoyable. I enjoyed the simple "Shoot knees or head, do a combo" system, rather than having to roll around dark souls style and melee manually. 

Also all the enemies that transform after you kill them are dialed up to 10 in the China sections, which is annoying. And instead of being scary and worrying like RE4 or 5, they just amount to making the enemies more tedious to defeat. 

Only recommend buying it if you have a co-op partner to play it with, otherwise. Stay away.

Resident Evil 6 surprised the hell out of me — in the BEST way. I don’t care what the haters say… this game is GOATED if you actually play and enjoy the story.

First, let me talk about the storylines. Bro… FOUR campaigns?? Leon, Chris, Jake (yeah Wesker’s son—tough dude), and my MOMMY, QUEEN, GODDESS Ada Wong. The fact that each campaign connects and forms one giant story is crazy. It feels like watching an entire Resident Evil universe unfold in front of you.

Leon’s campaign? Beautiful mix of horror and action.
Chris’s campaign? Military action heartbreak.
Jake’s campaign? The next generation stepping into the chaos.
Ada’s campaign? Bro… peak cinema. She just walks in, saves the day, acts mysterious, disappears, and looks GORGEOUS doing it.

I’ve supervised Leon and Ada’s story since RE2, followed them again in RE4 Remake, and now seeing their dynamic continue in RE6… DAMN. The chemistry is insane. Their relationship is that legendary “I save you, you save me, but we're still complicated as hell” type of story. I LOVE IT.

And Ada in RE6?
Bruh.
The outfit, the attitude, the voice, the moves — CHEF’S. KISS.
Capcom knew exactly what they were doing. Every cutscene with her? I stopped breathing. That’s MY secret campaign.

Gameplay?
Fire.
Smooth movement, sick melee combos, cinematic moments, and the fact that you can play the whole thing with co-op makes it even better. Not many RE games give you FOUR full campaigns that interlock so perfectly.

People can hate all they want, but RE6 is ambitious, crazy fun, and full of iconic moments. If you love Leon, Chris, Jake, or especially ADA WONG (my personal religion), this game is a must-play.

Resident Evil 6 is a game that tries to do too much at once, and ends up losing the identity that defined the series. The constant shift in tone and gameplay between campaigns makes the experience feel inconsistent and unfocused, often leaning more toward loud action than tense survival horror. The pacing frequently suffers, overwhelmed by explosions, quick-time events, and set pieces that leave little room for atmosphere or suspense. That said, there are some positives. The game offers a large amount of content, with multiple campaigns and co-op support that can be enjoyable with a friend. Some character moments still land, and at times the combat can be entertaining when it slows down long enough to breathe. Visually, the game holds up decently, and the soundtrack and sound design are solid. However, these strengths aren’t enough to outweigh the feeling that Resident Evil 6 lost track of what made the franchise unique. It’s a bold experiment with scale and ambition, but one that traded identity and coherence for spectacle.

But, the Ada campaign came. The last one to provide even more context.
In all previous adventures at least you have some duo to provide any dynamics, dialogues and just fill the time between the shooting. Yes, mostly they suck, but at least they were there in the story. Ada campaign was originally designed to be a single player experience, but you can play it in co-op mode (like I did with my friend). Honestly, with wannabe a cinematic experience RE6 tries to provide I never supposed I could be even more disappointed. Don't buy this game thinking it will be more RE5, because that's what I did and oh boy was I wrong...

This game... I'm not sure if Capcom ever finished it, to be honest; It feels so "raw" and unpolished it's crazy to think that somebody play-tested this and said "yeah, this is good". What happened here, seriously? Does anybody know? My only guess is that they were in a real rush to push out the next mainline entry for some reason, but the end product is a good moral lesson on how good things take time.

I won't bore you with how this game feels nothing like a Resident Evil game because if you've played Resident Evil 4 and 5 you should be used to this franchise's action game phase by now, and yes; It definitely does feel like some summer blockbuster shlock that Michael Bay would direct, complete with cheesy dialogue and one-liners that make you roll your eyes so hard you could count every wrinkle in your brain. I hope you're not attached to any of this universe's characters because RE6 turns them into unlikeable one-note stereotypes and misogynists.

The graphics? Let's talk about the graphics: The phrase "this looks like a PS2 game" is often misused in my opinion, because a lot of the big budget games on that platform looked pretty damn good. So when I say "RE6 looks like a PS2 game", I should clarify that it specifically looks like a *bad* PS2 game; Ugly texture seams, low poly character models, weird shader effects that make some objects appear extraordinarily shiny... You can stumble upon random 3D objects that emit light bloom as if they're christmas decorations... A ton of world objects aren't scaled properly, so be prepared to find huge chairs and toilets.

Sure; Graphics aren't everything, but RE6's visual presentation is a huge step back compared to 5, which still holds up pretty well in the graphics department.

The controls? Complete ass, no question. Movement direction is controlled by both the mouse and the WASD keys, so your character movement always feels imprecise and squirrelly. I'd much rather take RE5s tank controls over this, because even after 46 hours of playing I never feel 100% like I know what I'm doing. Even worse is that the game loves to start cutscenes seemingly at random, and give you control back when the camera is at a different angle that changes where your character moves; This happens *so* many times, yet you will never be prepared for it and it will cause a significant amount of your deaths.

I've read some of the more recent reviews say that they enjoy the controls and how "fast paced" it is, but I'm not sure what these people are smoking...

How about the music? Sure, music hasn't always been on the forefront of the franchise, but it has definitely been memorable and helped build the game's iconic atmosphere and suspense. Here, it sounds like a generic royalty free orchestra soundtrack; It almost never feels appropriate and at worst will make you hunt for the mute / volume button. Same goes for the sound effects: Prepare to hear a whole library of familiar sounding stock sounds. I was half expecting to hear a Wilhelm Scream.

The story is... Bad. It's just not good. It's basically an attempt at turning Resident Evil into a story that spans the globe, but it only limits us to a handful of locations, and besides a change of scenery you'll be fighting essentially the same three or four small groups of enemies over and over again but with different "skins". I will say that the concept of intersecting storylines is novel and an interesting idea conceptually, but Capcom did not pull it off well here and most of the story intersections and how they relate to one another introduce plotholes more than anything else. At no point does the writing ever feel like a fully realized Resident Evil game; It teeters on bad fan-fiction.

Would I recommend it? Steam reviews only allow for positive and negative reviews, so it's hard to provide a nuanced opinion sometimes, but I think it depends mostly on your tolerance of bad games and if you have somebody to play it with. If you're someone who enjoys the occasional bad media (i.e. The Room or Birdemic) and you have a friend who does too, then I think RE6 can be a blast. I know I was laughing almost every other cutscene, for sure. That being said, I don't think you'll get much enjoyment out of playing this by yourself.
